pr_title: [CALCITE-4081] Round-tripping a DECIMAL literal throws validation error

timeline.bodyText: Seems the toType should always be a Decimal type, we should add a check here. Also, can we add some doc to this method ?
timeline.author: danny0405

replies.bodyText:
Seems the toType should always be a Decimal type, we should add a check here

Not necessary. It would work even though toType is not Decimal since  I used case when.

Also, can we add some doc to this method ?

Makes sense.
replies.author: chunweilei

replies.bodyText: If toType is not decimal, how can you ensure that it has a valid precision and scale, such as -1.
replies.author: danny0405

replies.bodyText: Do you want to throw an exception if toType is not decimal by saying "add a check here"?
replies.author: chunweilei

replies.bodyText: I just want to make sure the logic is robust, either a check or assert is okey from  my side.
replies.author: danny0405

timeline.bodyText: Why change the query ? It works in MySql and PostgresSQL.
timeline.author: danny0405

replies.bodyText:
It overflows.
chunwei.lcw@chunwei:~$ psql
psql (12.3)
Type "help" for help.

chunwei.lcw=# select cast('111.23' as decimal(4, 2));
ERROR:  numeric field overflow
DETAIL:  A field with precision 4, scale 2 must round to an absolute value less than 10^2.
replies.author: chunweilei

replies.bodyText: Hmm, it seems only MySql succeed, with a result of 99.99 for query select cast('123.45' as decimal(4, 2))
replies.author: danny0405

replies.bodyText: We may need to have a conclusion for this behavior change, it seems breaking.
replies.author: danny0405

replies.bodyText: Yep. But from what I can see, cast('123.45' as decimal(4, 2)) should not return 123.45.
replies.author: chunweilei
